title: Color Accessibility
description: Learn principles of accessible design using colors

intro.title: Introduction
intro.content: Accessible design ensures that your content can be used by all people, including those with visual impairments or color blindness.

wcag.title: WCAG Contrast Guidelines
wcag.content: WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) sets contrast standards to ensure text readability:

aa.title: Level AA
aa.desc: Minimum contrast of 4.5:1 for normal text and 3:1 for large text. This is the minimum standard for most websites.

aaa.title: Level AAA
aaa.desc: High contrast of 7:1 for normal text and 4.5:1 for large text. Recommended for important content.

colorBlindness.title: Color Blindness Considerations
colorBlindness.content: About 8% of men and 0.5% of women have some form of color blindness. It's important not to rely solely on color to convey information:

items.0: Use icons and text along with color
items.2: Test designs using color blindness simulation tools

readability.title: Text Readability
readability.content: Good text readability is critical for accessibility. Ensure text has sufficient contrast with the background, use large enough fonts, and avoid overly bright or dark combinations.

alternatives.title: Alternative Color Indicators
alternatives.content: Don't rely solely on color to convey important information. Use additional visual indicators: shapes, icons, text, patterns, or symbols.
